fields.description:
Recently Microsoft has finally released their Team Foundation Service.
It's good place to host your projects, it supports Visual Studio CVS (TFS - Team Foundation Server) and Git, using their own git-tf command line utility.

SourceTree is a wonderful app, which unfortunately supports only 4 git hosts. Would be nice if it could support the 5th :) 
So requesting add support of TFS for SourceTree for Mac :)
fields.summary: TFS-GIt integration support

fields.description:
Since upgrading to Mavericks my "Bookmarks" window seems to be a law unto itself, the only way I can get it under control is to manually move it back to it's correct desktop/workspace by using expose, or quit it and re-launch it.

Every time I click on the Sourcetree icon in the dock it relocates the bookmarks window to whichever workspace I'm currently in instead of going to the SourceTree desktop/workspace.

The repo windows seem to stay in the correct desktop, which makes it even more difficult to keep control of everything.
fields.summary: Sourcetree bookmarks relocates to current desktop/workspace when clicking on dock icon

fields.description: I've been suffering quite frequent crashes in SourceTree, seemingly while doing just about any git operation they can occur. I haven't really spotted a pattern to them, will it be any help if I start submitting crash reports like these for analysis?
fields.summary: Crash Report

fields.description: I ran into the same issue as https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREE-1444, and thought it was a bug. It may be better to rephrase the "Tag with this message" prompt to something like: "Attach a message to the tag".
fields.summary: Rephrase prompt for Flow tagging

fields.description:
Little thought seems to have been given to enabling standard workflows from the keyboard.

Example: Reviewing recent commits requires alternately clicking on the commit list and the file list for the current commit.  There is no way to scroll (forward or backward) the differences list from the keyboard.

Proposal 1: Go through standard workflows and make sure they can be operated from the keyboard.
Proposal 2: Document keyboard bindings.
fields.summary: Keyboard Shortcuts for Work Flows

fields.description:
With larger repositories it's difficult to tell which branch you're on when selecting commits in the log view, so explicitly show the branch for each commit somewhere (probably the commit detail view).

Reported via AAC here: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/223644/how-to-show-branch-column-in-log-view-sourcetree?page=1#227377

EDIT: As Yoriz reported, we already added this, so it's desired that it should be a column in the log view. This would definitely be an opt-in if decided upon as a go-ahead.
fields.summary: Branch name in log view column

fields.description: Escalated from STSP-825 (Leo Wang)
fields.summary: Mavericks Crash

fields.description:
Ideally if using the git flow workflow one would like to simply clone a git repo then run the git-flow initialization on it from SourceTree. The problem is that if you do it, it fails unless master is the default branch.

For us, the default branch is develop as master is just an empty placeholder branch (with nothing but a .gitignore) because there has been no release yet. Since there is nothing on master, I would like to keep develop as the default branch. If I try to init gitflow it says it cannot create the production branch.

The only way to get this to work is to create the tracking branch for master. Since I already have a refs/remotes/origin/master it would be very nice if SourceTree offered to just create the tracking branch for master for me.
fields.summary: Git clone then init git flow does not work unless default branch is master

fields.description: I work on projects with tons of local and remote branches and whenever SourceTree refreshes the repo (which is quite frequent) the sidebar jumps to the top. It make me lose my spot where I was looking, which is trivial, yet annoying. However sometimes I go to double click on a branch to check it out and the repo will refresh and I'll end up double clicking the wrong branch.
fields.summary: Prevent sidebar from scrolling to top when refresh occurs

fields.description: When using the Setup Wizard's Find local repositories, repositories inside repositories are not found. For example, I have a tutorials repository where I make subdirectories for various tutorials that I'm working through. Occasionally, these tutorials involve cloning a repository, so I clone them into the tutorial directory, and add them to .gitignore. It may be better for me to use submodules for this, but I'm not sure, as not all of my sub repositories are git repositories.
fields.summary: Setup Wizard: Find local repositories and nested repos

fields.description:
The Find local repositories search in the Setup Wizard does not find repositories whose directory names start with '.'. This may be because the Finder treats these as hidden files.

As an example, I keep my Emacs configuration in a .emacs.d directory, which is a git repository. I have other similar repositories. I pointed the search at my home directory, and it did not find any of these.
fields.summary: Setup Wizard: Find local repositories and .repos

fields.description:
Noticed an issue with Add Remote. It actually is allowing you to paste new lines into the URL.

I copied the URL from bitbucket page telling me how to push an existing repository to a new repo, but I didn't realize that I managed to copy the end of line as well.

When pasted into the add remote nothing shows in the URL field because it is showing you the blank line after the line feed. That made me think I didn't paste it and I pasted it again, same result.

When completing the dialog, what I got in .git/config was the URL twice with \n after both. This leads to bizarre errors like:
  conq:invalid repository syntax.
  fatal: Could not read from remote repository.

So you might want to better handle extraneous whitespace.
fields.summary: Ignore extraneous white space when adding remote

fields.description: Today SourceTree crashed for me (it worked fine yesterday and the day before when I upgraded OS X to 10.9 mavericks). When I tried to reopen it, it asked if it should restore windows; I clicked "Yes" and it crashed again. When I reopened it again and clicked not to restore windows this time, it crashed as well. :/ I can't open it at all currently.
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes at start

fields.description:
Installed Source tree from DMG downloaded from http://www.sourcetreeapp.com/download/

The app icon is fine in applications, but once opened there is only a "blank" icon in dock and application switcher. see attached img. of dock.

I have used Sourcetree thru all the dev. releases of OSX 10.9 and it has not shown this bug there.

I have tried uninstalling sourcetree and all references without success. (Using appdelete to remove all references that sourcetree might create)
fields.summary: Blank icon in dock and app switcher on OS X 10.9

fields.description: http://screencast.com/t/bDCwQEBth
fields.summary: Infinite error messages loop when a repository directory is deleted

fields.description: http://screencast.com/t/t0bK5G0u
fields.summary: Error appears when unstaging last lines of file

fields.description: Feels like with every with every release recently the app get slower and slower. It seems like it requests a complete update of state after every tiniest action. It's merely impossible to work with it right now.
fields.summary: Unbearably slow performance of the app

fields.description: When using a git command from an external environment (e.g. terminal) I refresh sourcetree to get the changes, but the icons on the top horizontal toolbar still have the old status. They get to the current status after some time interval, e.g. 1-2 minutes.
fields.summary: The toolbar icons do not get updated when refreshing

fields.description:
Need All in one windows the same like Windows version sourcetree.
I am using sourcetree for both windows and macos.
the macos version software is not very well. because it lacks the all in one window. 
I am tracking more than 50 git repository. 
Under macos, the sourcetree behaviors very ugly.
fields.summary: Need All in one windows the same like Windows version sourcetree

fields.description:
I want to clone more than 10 repository via sourcetree, but i want the tasks runs at background.
If there be any solution, such as background batch working or background task list running (we can control max proccess running the same time)
fields.summary: Add background batch proccess or background proccess list

fields.description:
When committing changes, I will often select "push to remote" so changes are instantly uploaded to my remote git server. When a connection is not available, SourceTree will obviously state that the push failed. The commit seems to still be successful, but the UI does not update to show the new commit.

I would expect, even when the push fails in this circumstance, for the commit to succeed and show up in the commit history and the push badge to update and show that there are commits that need to be pushed. Instead, the UI shows no changes (no commits and no push changes). When I re-establish a connection and push changes to the server, SourceTree shows that there was a successful commit and then pushes it to the remote server. After the push, the UI successfully updates to show all commits.
fields.summary: UI Does Not Update On Commit/Push Fail

fields.description: When hitting the return key you go into rename mode as expected, however you should be able to exit rename mode by hitting the escape key.
fields.summary: Escape key doesn't exit rename mode in bookmarks

fields.description:
You can now open the window with Cmd+B, navigate it with the arrows but you can't a select a repo to open (enter goes into rename).

This is a shame as you need to go grab the mouse.

Another nice addition is to allow using the keyboard to navigate to repos by typing letters in their name.
fields.summary: Add a keyboard shortcut te select a repo from the benchmark window

fields.description: In Mac OS X 10.9 Mavericks (updated from 10.8) the SourceTreeApp crashes when I try to start it. JDK 7 40.
fields.summary: Sourcetreeapp crashes when it is started (Mac OS X 10.9)

fields.description: SourceTree 1.7.3 constantly crashes on my machine, running Mac OS X 10.9, build 13A598. The app doesn't start at all.
fields.summary: SourceTree 1.7.3 constantly crashing on Mac OS X 10.9

fields.description:
It is a really annoying to remove the mail address from the author field by hand for EACH commit.

When leaving the global (or repo) config entry empty, the commit author states sth like "name <>", with empty brackets at the end, which is kind of unnecessary.

Tried this with hg, but i guess this affects git as well.

Thanks for your help!

Marcel
fields.summary: Allow commits without email entry.

fields.description:
Use Version 1.7.3 (1.7.3)
- Set Allow Force Push in Options DIalog
- Click on Push button
- Resize Push dialog

ACT: all controls are moved according to dialog size/position, but Force Push is frozen on previous position. See screenshot

EXP: Force Push should be repositioned as well as other controls
fields.summary: Force push checkbox doesn't relocate when I resize Push To Repository dialog

fields.description:
I'm using Mac version sourcetree1.7.3. I've set the diff tool as "Other" and point to my vimdiff path, the Arguments is "-d $LOCAL $REMOTE". Then use the External Diff button, there is only LOCAL file but no REMOTE file. My macvim hint the REMOTE file path is /private/var/folders/m4/f_hd3wgd3xv4_7gch2r4p3h80000gn/T/HNkd6f_test.py
But there is no such file.

See: https://bitbucket.org/site/master/issue/8280/custom-diff-tool-does-not-work
fields.summary: Custom diff tool does not work

fields.description:
Using Standalone.

Since sourcetree 1.7.2 I have experienced a situation where sourcetree runs for a certain amount of commits at its usual snappy speed, then starts to slow down till it gets to the point that I'm waiting up to 20 seconds for it to refresh my folders and then huge lag issues like if I try to drag folders / files from my working tree to stage them, they end up all over the place (like my desktop) cause ST can't keep up with the UI. The only thing that fixes this is restarting ST. As soon as I close it and restart it is straight back to its snappy old self.

The git repos I am using are quite small - normally less than 20mb with no more than 600 files so they aren't huge team efforts - just small websites.
fields.summary: Sourcetree is epic slow after several commits with a lot of lag

fields.description:
In the Git Push dialog, there is a 'Force Push' option. The option label and checkbox has a fixed position, so that if you enlarge the dialog window, they do not move as expected. See screenshots for details.

To reproduce:

- Open a Git repository in SouceTree (with a valid remote repo)
- Click on the Push button, so that dialog opens up
- Drag the bottom of the dialog so that expands vertically

Expected behaviour:

- The controls below the Branches window move with the bottom
of the dialy - Select All, Push All Tags, Force Push, Cancel, OK.

Actual behaviour:

- Everything except 'Force Push' moves as expected. FP stays where it
was when the window first opened.
fields.summary: "Force Push" checkbox in Push dialog has fixed position

fields.description:
I inserted a single line in a .php file (as attached), and the internal diff shows the whole file to be changed, while the external one correctly shows the affected line. 

I would expect the internal diff to behave like the external one.
fields.summary: For any single change the internal diff shows the whole file to be altered (while external diff works)

fields.description:
The icons on the left sidebar are still the old ones, which were replaced a while ago. Tags still have the old icon tag, stashes have that cardboard box, etc. 

As much as I liked the old icons, the interface would make more sense if the same branch, tag, and stash icons on the top toolbar were used next to your branches, tags, and stashes on the left sidebar.
fields.summary: Old icons are still used on left sidebar

fields.description:
According to instructions on https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorial/remote-repositories#!pull page I've executed following command {code}git config --global branch.autosetuprebase always{code} to force git using "rebase" instead of "merge", when doing a "git pull" command.

It seems, that SourceTree doesn't read this setting value and on Pull Dialog the "Rebase instead of merge" checkbox isn't checked by default.
fields.summary: Setting "branch.autosetuprebase" of Git not respected in Pull dialog

fields.description:
See description here:
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/221624/sourcetree-crashes-immediately-upon-opening-git-repo

and crash log here:
https://www.dropbox.com/s/lunakyf0hjng4nl/st_crash.log
fields.summary: Crash on opening repository

fields.description: Check the screenshot to see how large diffs are handled by Sourcetree
fields.summary: Large diffs make Diff visualization background broken

fields.description:
In the file status list, long filenames/paths are truncated with ellipses if they don't fit within the available column width (e.g. [^file-list-truncated.png]). This can make it difficult to see what's going.

It would be nice to be able to resize the column so I can scroll horizontally and see the full name.

There's a hacky workaround which I sometimes use:

The columns can be reordered by dragging them to a new position. If the _final_ column is resizable (i.e. filename or path) then resizing the pane will cause that column to be resized to match the available width of that pane, truncating names if they don't fit. The other columns won't be affected.

However, the status column isn't resizable. If this column is the last position then the filename/path columns can be resized as desired and won't be affected when resizing the pane (e.g. [^file-list-horizontal-scroll.png]).

(SRCTREE-1273 may be related but I think it refers to another part of the UI.)
fields.summary: horizontal scroll in file status list

fields.description:
One click to push git branch to multiple remote repository.
 
I am a developer, i maintained multiple repository. the same code will push to mutiple remote.

i have 3 remote repository :
1. main repository: for all developers
2. the archive repository: for backup purpose.
3. the personal repository: my working hardly repository.

i want to push my master branch to both 3 repository by one click. 

because daily working need push code very often , i need help to made it easier to do push.

i want to push my local  master branch to 

remote
           main/master
           archive/master
           my/master

can this be more quickly? just one click to push branch to three.
fields.summary: One click to push git branch to multiple remote repository

fields.description: i closed SourceTree with force quit many times when it was freeze. I attached my crash report file.
fields.summary: Sourcetree freeze sometimes when i send to commits to server (git push).

fields.description:
Currently, to the best of my knowledge, there is no way to discard all unstaged changes like you can unstage all staged changes.

I think the discard button "should" do this? It is currenlty discarding the whole file, including all staged changes.
fields.summary: Unintuitive Behavior for Discard When Some Changes Are Staged (All Changes Are Lost)

fields.description: It'd be nice if there was some option to hide tags from the log view.
fields.summary: I'd like a way to hide tags from displaying in the log view

fields.description:
I wish the search didn't force me to pick a search type (user/files/sha/etc).

Why can't I just type whatever term I'm looking for in the search box and the app looks everywhere it can for matches? If I realize that the results were too broad, *then* I could try to narrow down a little more.
fields.summary: Simpler search

fields.description:
I've got two commits with one being a direct child of the other and no merging involved, but in "Date Order" they're being displayed in the wrong order (and therefore the graph doesn't connect).

Both commits have exactly the same timestamp in the "Commit Date" header so I think the sort algorithm could do with some improvement to cope with this case.

My guess is that it works like this at the moment:

# Sort by the "Commit Date" header
# If that's equal then sort by the "Date" header

Whereas if it worked like this it'd give the correct result:

# Sort by the "Commit Date" header
# If that's equal then sort by any direct parent/child relationships
# If there are no/missing relationships then sort by the "Date" header

(The reason for the "Date" headers being the reverse of what you might expect is that I did a rebase to swap the order of the commits)
fields.summary: Incorrect date ordering when two commits have the same timestamp

fields.description: SourceTree has become very slow of late and literally freezes for several seconds with a beachball. In addition, there's almost always a lag while typing in the commit window. I think this all has to do with the background refreshes that are going on. Weird part is on my second MBP with the exact same specs, where I have only 2 small repositories, I still see this lag. It's getting to the point where I'm thinking of going back to SmartGit as it's hurting productivity.
fields.summary: SourceTree has become very slow and frequently beachballs

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
# Open a repository in SourceTree and click the "Pull" button.
# Select "Custom" in the first drop-down menu.
# Enter the URL of another repository other than your origin (typically the URL of a fork of your remote).

The "Remote branch to pull" drop-down menu should contain the list of the remote branches of the custom repository but it actually contains the list of the remote branches of the "origin" remote defined for this repository. Clicking on "Refresh" changes the branch listing but it still doesn't populate it correctly.

A common use case when this is problematic is when doing a merge of a GitHub Pull Request (from a fork of a repository).

For example, if a repository is at https://github.com/me/foo.git and someone forked the repository in https://github.com/other/foo.git and pushed some changes on a branch which was named "bugfix-1234" on that repository. To then propose a pull request from GitHub, this can't be manually pulled to merge it using SourceTree, as  the "bugfix-1234" branch of other/foo.git is not in the drop-down menu, but only the remote branches of the me/foo.git repo.
fields.summary: Inconsistent Remote Branches List When Pulling From a Custom Repository

fields.description: When deleting a branch, if the branch name is quite long, SourceTree will cut it off in the dialog box without proper truncation.
fields.summary: Long Branch Names Are Cut Off In Delete Dialog

fields.description: In the branch list and in the main commit list, as sourcetree loads things, the scroll position jumps around constantly, causing me to have to scroll back to where I was looking over and over.
fields.summary: Scroll position changes out from under you constantly

fields.description: It would be a very helpful and convenient new feature to allow users to easily and quickly access their remote github repos via a web browser from the Remotes context menu. I suggest a new menu item called "Open Project On Github" which would launch the user's web browser (allowing us to choose which browser, chrome, safari, firefox, etc) and land them on the associated github project page.
fields.summary: Add "Open Project On Github" menu item on Remotes context menu

# I am using a project with sub-modules

fields.description:
Support pushing only some commits using the syntax:

git push <remote> <commit SHA>:<remote_branch>
fields.summary: Push only some commits

fields.description: Please allow for searching for commits or at least for closed branches in Log tab (by pressing Cmd+F).
fields.summary: Searching for commits and closed branches

fields.description:
Hi!

I have a suggestion for improvement for your app.

When looking in the diff view for uncommited changes,
it would be awesome to be able to edit the code directly there.

Because oftentimes in Xcode,
I put comments where I am going to change the code,
but those could be scattered throughout the code.
And it takes a while to jump between the comments,
but in your app the code changes are gathered in one view.

Kind regards,
Johan
fields.summary: editing in the diff view

fields.description:
1. Open interactive rebase
2. Check an "Amend Commit" checkbox
3. Click "Edit Message" button

All interface elements in the modal dialog are grayed out. Must force quitting the application. See attachment for example.
fields.summary: SourceTree UI lockup in interactive rebase dialog

fields.description:
Aside of the "Current Branch" and "All Branches" filter, it would be useful to have a "Current Branch and All Descendents" option.
This would show the commits of the current branch, and everything that is based off of it.
Often I am trying to get a sense of what my team is working. My team works off of a feature/story branch. This feature would help me filter out all other activity (from other teams) and just reveal what my team is working on.
fields.summary: "Current Branch and Descendants"

fields.description:
In the log view, select a merge commit, which has two parents. The file comparison appears to be done between the selected commit and the second parent - d and c in the diagram below.
{noformat}
o --- d
|\
| o - c
| |
o | - b
|/
o --- a
{noformat}
Since there is no reason to choose one parent (b or c) over the other, it is arbitrary to compare d with c. So, either there should be an option for the user to choose that branch with which to compare and/or, the comparison should be made with the merge-base, so that d is compared with a. In the latter case, it would be useful to be able to invoke an external tool with a three-way merge on d with b and c.
fields.summary: Differences for merge commit are arbitrary

fields.description:
Sometimes git commits have incorrect parent resolution. If I look at the "Parents" field and click on a link, it goes to a correct node but the GUI displays them disconnected.

If I scroll down to the very first commit in the repo, the lines from commits presented incorrectly are still present, see the screenshots.

All of it was checked on the Sizzle repository: https://github.com/jquery/sizzle
fields.summary: Incorrect parent commit resolution

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
# Select a file called "config.php" in the Working Copy to see uncommitted changes.
# Switch to the Log view and look at a specific commit.
# Select a file from that commit (eg. controller.php).
# Right click on that file and select "Open Current Version".
# The default editor will open the file "config.php" and not "controller.php".
fields.summary: "Open Current Version" Opens Wrong File

fields.description: To address the confusion for newcomers to rebase as illustrated in these comments: http://blog.sourcetreeapp.com/2012/08/21/merge-or-rebase/#comment-1057552677
fields.summary: Add preview to rebase confirmation dialog

fields.description:
A remote host is set up like this:
{code}
[remote "gitolite"]
	url = git@XXX.XXX.XXX.XXX:odyssey
	fetch = +refs/heads/*:refs/remotes/gitolite/*
	gtSSHKey = /Users/immo/.ssh/id_rsa_gitolite
{code}
The connection worked fine, but suddenly after starting SourceTree again after a reboot, the connection stopped working with this error message:
{code}
git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false -c credential.helper=sourcetree fetch gitolite 

Permission denied (publickey,gssapi-keyex,gssapi-with-mic).
fatal: The remote end hung up unexpectedly
{code}

I've tried to deinstall SourceTree and then install it again which solved it for a while but after starting SourceTree again the connection problem came back again.

Strangely it can still tell me that there are 6 changes I need to pull (and that number was updated from when SourceTree started). I am not sure whether it needed to connect to the remote server for that info or whether that info was available locally (I did try to pull via Eclipse earlier)

Connecting with Eclipse works fine with the same ssh key
fields.summary: Connecting to remote repository via ssh and ssh keys fails after working fine before

fields.description: When clicking on "Checkout in Sourcetree" in the branch actions dropdown, Sourcertree shows a dialog with the correct branch name in the "local branch" text field, but the remote branch is 'default'. There is no such branch name in my repo, and continuing with the checkout, another dialog asks if i want to pull changes from origin/default, which I don't want to do, I just want to check out the branch. That branch already exists locally and is set to track the remote.
fields.summary: Checkout in Sourcetree doesn't get the right branch name

fields.description:
I have about 20 projects open in github and from time to time I get SourceTree hanged with the spin ball for ever. If I force quit it I get the crash report included. This typically happens when there is an Internet connection glitch. I suspect that lost of connectivity is the root of that problem.

Cheers

Pierre
fields.summary: too many dispatch threads blocked in synchronous operations

fields.description: Often when I have a clean local repository, there are a few untracked files. Sometimes these are leftovers from merging (*.orig, *BACKUP*, etc.). It would be convenient if I could drag the leftovers to the trash, or right-click and delete them within SourceTree, instead of deleting them in a separate shell.
fields.summary: Add ability to delete non-tracked files

fields.description: When looking at the list of commits, I'd like to do Command-F to pop up a find bar to search. The search should match hashes and comments of the commits.
fields.summary: Search commits

fields.description:
SourceTree 1.7.0 added the ability to create pull requests.

This is great, except I didn't realize it was there. I suspect many others still don't. Please add Pull Request to the toolbar (possibly, conditionally; only when it applies) so this is more discoverable.

(It's also a feature I'd use many times per day.)
fields.summary: Add Create Pull Request to toolbar

fields.description: The dialog for "Fetch" does not save the selected checkboxes when called a second time. It would be nice to have the selected options saved by default for future reference.
fields.summary: Save Fetch Options For Future Reference

fields.description: e.g. the branch "feature-description(#155)" is shown as "feature-description" -> no change to this branch is possible!!
fields.summary: Branch names with in parentheses formatting

fields.description:
I'm using the desktop version of SourceTree on OSX. Please allow me to bypass this extra click! You could add a new preference for me to uncheck "Confirm settings before pulling"

Just take the action based on my prior settings instead of making me click 3 times! For some reason, sourcetree also doesn't hide the "Pull" settings once the pull is complete so I have to manually close it each time.
fields.summary: When I click "Pull" from the menu bar, just pull based on my last settings and hide the settings panel when it's done pulling. Instead of asking EVERY TIME!

fields.description:
I'm using the desktop version of SourceTree on OSX. Please allow me to bypass this extra click! You could add a new preference for me to uncheck "Confirm setting before fetching"

This is true of clicking "pull" and "push" as well. Just take the action based on my prior settings instead of making me click 3 times!
fields.summary: When I click "fetch" from the menu bar, just fetch based on my last settings instead of asking EVERY TIME!

fields.description: We have our own Enterprise distribution of Github (as i expect most of your big users do) and i would love to try the new submit pull request feature, but when trying to configure the remote server in settings selecting a host type of GitHub hard codes (seen in the field below it) the Host Root URL, it would be awesome if that could be changed.
fields.summary: Allow custom base URL for GitHub Enterprise distributions

fields.description: I find myself needing both a "show pending flat view" and a "show all tree view" at the same time.  I both need to check my workspace status and browse the repro.  It seems odd that you cannot create multiple "file status" views at the same time.
fields.summary: multiple "file status" views

fields.description:
If you have a branch "ACME" and a branch "ACME/Wile E. Coyote",
usually on the left hand side under "BRANCHES" you see a list of the currently active branches. If branches contain a "/", this is considered as folder structure.

Assuming the following structure, this should work:
* ACME/Wile E. Coyote
* ACME/Road Runner

{noformat}
- ACME
    - Wile E. Coyote
    - Road Runner
{noformat}
But only the part before the first slash is shown.
fields.summary: Branch Collation Hides Existing Branches With Same Name Start

fields.description: Any search when the 'File Changes' option is selected does not return any results.
fields.summary: search for 'File Changes' not working

fields.description:
When using the pull icon, the latest version of source tree consistently shows "no changes", where prior versions showed the output if <hg in>. 

This is true with a small or large number of oncoming changes.

We are using Mercurial on bitbucket

I can verify that <hg in> is returning a list in incoming changesets via the command line.

-r
fields.summary: Latest version (1.7.0.1) does not show changes when pulling

fields.description:
gpg --list-secret-keys shows me all my secret keys, but when I'm trying to enable commit signing in repository preferences the error message 
bq. Cannont enable GPG signing of commits, there are no GPG keys available
comes up.

Your help file told me to file a bug report in this case.
fields.summary: No GPG-Keys available for commit signing
crash report

fields.description:
I have three SourceTree windows open - each a different & completely unrelated git repo. All are in normal (non-rebasing, non-detached-head) state.

In one window, I select a commit from the list, right-click and select "Rebase children of xxx interactively." I check the Amend box on one of the commits and start the rebase. With/without making changes, I press Commit and confirm the amend.

At this point, one of the background SourceTree windows takes focus, momentarily shows the "Continuing rebase" action sheet before showing an alert saying "No rebase in progress" (http://ss.cpfx.ca/Kbxao.png). I dismiss this dialog, only to have the process repeat for the second background SourceTree window. 

At this point, the rebase has completed successfully in the intended repo, and no changes have been made to the other repos.

It seems like the rebase-continue message is being incorrectly propagated to every open repository/window.
fields.summary: Interactive rebase causes spurious alerts when multiple repository windows are open

fields.description:
After the most recent update of SourceTree (1.7.0.1) I am noticing that adding files to the index and then clicking Commit and the box that says "Amend latest commit", this will no longer fill in the original commit message. Instead, an error message gets printed in the commit message box:

fatal: ambiguous argument 'HEAD': both revision and filename
Use '--' to separate filenames from revisions

If I just blindly continue and do the amend (as I used to do), this will be used *as the commit message*, and the original message will be lost.

I believe this is new behavior to version 1.7.0.1.
fields.summary: Amending commits borks the commit message

fields.description:
In previous version when I open Expose for SourceTree there are recent repositories was there. And I could start type repository name and open it by enter key.

Now recent repositories disappear completely from Expose.

Bookmarks window (⌘B) is not replacement of this function because it does not have simple way to open selected repository: enter key edit repository name, not open it.
fields.summary: Recent repositories disappear from App Expose

fields.description:
During the upgrade of the Mercurial pull sheet to display the incoming changes fully, the 'Revision' option has been lost to allow people to pull a specific revision; only the 'Branch' option remains.

http://twitter.com/AddictArts/status/379862906633863168

We should bring this back if possible; this is dependent on it still being supportable with the bundle-based pull approach - check.
fields.summary: Restore the 'Revision' field in the Mercurial pull sheet

fields.description: When I try to use Mercurial 2.7.1 from http://mercurial.selenic.com, the patch fails with the error message depicted in the attached screenshot.
fields.summary: SourceTree 1.7.0.1 patch for system mercurial fails

fields.description:
Please support GitLab (http://gitlab.org) for the pull request option. 

GitLab is supporting via API to create Merge Requests (http://api.gitlab.org/merge_requests.html#create-mr) maybe it's easy to implement it with your current design on creating merge requests.
fields.summary: Pull Request Support for Gitlab

fields.description: When I try to open a fresh downloaded version of SourTree for Mac (from http://www.sourcetreeapp.com/download/), Mac OS X can not open the disk image (see the screenshot, in french).
fields.summary: Failed to open the DMG

fields.description:
While my system is in French, I want to be able to use SourceTree in English, you support the ability to change the localization, which is great, but it doesn't work here.
If I go to the General Preferences and select "English" as Language in the pop up menu, all the dynamic strings are broken, instead of saying "Checkout…" it says "SidebarCheckout" and a lot of strings throughout the application are like that. Anything that is dynamic is broken.
fields.summary: The Language function in Preferences is broken

fields.description: From support issue here: https://support.atlassian.com/browse/STSP-582
fields.summary: Scroll bug with very large repositories

fields.description:
When amending through an interactive rebase operation, an unchanged author field fails to trigger the --author flag. The field is prefilled with the user specified in Advanced Settings, not the current author of the commit. This blocks a user from changing a commit author to themselves.

Use case:
A string of commits has a different author (B@example.com) than the current operator (A@example.com). As the current operator, I am trying to use interactive rebase to set the string of commits to my user, but cannot. When I go to commit one of the incorrect commits, I find that my account (A@example.com) is already in the author field, but when I commit the --author flag is not used (maybe because it hasn't been changed) and the author is still the other user (B@example.com). A workaround is to put a space after my address so it is different (A@example.com ).

Why is this important?
When working with Gerrit, one cannot push a new commit unless they are the author. It is possible for others (B@example.com) to push alternative commits, but if there is a conflict when a merge happens then the original author (A@example.com) may need to rebase on master to ammend the commit.
fields.summary: Ammending a commit during interactive rebase fails to apply changes to Author

fields.description: If the commit fails to sign in hg it leaves the commit window open with no indication of what happened. Look for a way to improve this to inform the user of what to do next i.e. making sure gpg is setup correctly and that you could sign the commit afterwards in hg if needs be.
fields.summary: Failed signing from commit sheet in hg

fields.description: If I've only installed MacGPG2 and don't set the GPG Program in the SourceTree preferences then trying to sign a commit doesn't work. Provide extra help for the user to suggest /usr/local/MacGPG2/bin or auto-set that location if none is set
fields.summary: If MacGPG2 only installed then gpg2 call doesn't work out-the-box

fields.description: If the user hasn't got the guildelines turned on then the context menu option in the commit sheet shouldn't be available
fields.summary: 'Format to guidelines' conditionally available

fields.description: The 'Sign commit' check box on the commit sheet should have some alternative text (the yellow box popup when hovering) to say why it isn't enabled in the event GPG isn't enabled for some reason.
fields.summary: 'Sign commit' check box on commit sheet should have description text

fields.description: The label on the check box currently says 'Enable GPG key signing for commits'. It should say 'Enable GPG key signing for commits / tags' as tags can also be signed.
fields.summary: Security tab checkbox label improvement for GPG

fields.description:
If you tick the 'Enable GPG key signing for commits' on the security tab when GPG isn't installed the correct warning message is displayed, and you still can't select a key, but the check box remains turned on. It shouldn't allow the user to tick it (auto-untick) so the user doesn't get any false hope.

Error message is displayed correctly though
fields.summary: Enabling GPG without GPG leaves checkbox turned on

fields.description:
From Todd Bluhm on AAC here: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/173127/interactive-rebase-hangs?page=1#211123

"Hey Kieran,

I have run into the exact same issue as @Greg originally posted. I started an interactive rebase ran into some conflicts, fixed them, then continued the rebase and it just sits there spining forever. It doesn't hang so much as it just doesn't ever finish, so no crash logs, but an intersting notifcation does pop up in the console as soon as I continue the rebase, the message is "9/12/13 1:59:19.411 AM SourceTree[967]: File has no contents"

Sourcetree version: Version 1.6.4.1 (1.6.4.1)

Git Embedded Version: 1.7.11.1

Repo Path: /Users/toddbluhm/Development/JourneyScholar/Lessontrek/code

SourceTree Path: /Applications/SourceTree"
fields.summary: GRI hangs

fields.description:
In the Commit sheet, the "Bypass commit hooks" checkbox is inset a few more pixels than the checkboxes above.

I know... trival cosmetic issue, but it keeps staring me in the face every time I commit. :-)
fields.summary: "Bypass commit hooks" checkbox inset

fields.description:
Frequently when working in the main SourceTree window for a repository, I'll be working in the working copy and need to open a file (e.g. to resolve a merge conflict).

I will right-click and bring up the contextual menu to "Open".

This is alright, but sometimes I need to open it in a specific application. For example, I need to edit a .html file. If I merely "open" it, it will open in Safari, which is not what I want to resolve that conflict. Instead, having an option to "Open With" (and presenting a submenu of apps that could open files of that type... just like the Finder does), would be greatly helpful. That way I could be sure to open the conflicted .html file in TextWrangler or TextMate or whatever may be most appropriate.

It would also be useful if this would be sure to open the file. For example, when an Xcode project file's .pbxproj file is conflicted in a merge, a simple "open" fails to work because the file is technically within a package and thus cannot just be opened by the Finder. If Open With (and/or Open) could open the actual file, that'd be great... but I know that's a bit harder to do in a generalized manner.

Anyways, Open With would strive to replicate how the Finder works in this regard, if at all possible. Being able to dynamically build a list of apps on the user's system and present them. Also an option to select "Other..." if needed.  If it's not possible or is too costly to generate that list of apps, having a SourceTree preferences panel would be cool to help handle files of particular types... e.g. for files with this extension, use this app to open it. Prepopulate with a lot of known and common extensions, allow ease of editing those mappings, and if something is selected via "Other..", automatically pick up that new mapping.
fields.summary: "Open with" command

fields.description: We are a Mac and Linux Development shop. We are seriously digging Sourcetree on Mac. Is there any outlook for Sourcetree on Linux as well???
fields.summary: SourceTree for Linux

fields.description:
The way I work with git is to do all of my development in a branch on my machine, then when I want to share it I pull down 'master' and rebase my local branch on top of that, finally merging down to master and pushing to the server.

This keeps a nice linear history whilst also allowing me to always cleanly pull new changes down from the server and resolve any conflicts during a rebase.

This workflow works really well in SourceTree, *except* that when I push to the server, my local branch is listed in the dialog. What I'd love is that I could exclude 'local branches' from the push dialog. That way I would never accidentally push it out and would always be safe to rebase.
fields.summary: create a 'local-only' branch that you can NEVER push, so it is always safe to rebase with

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
# Create an SVN repository with 2 branches.
# Create a local Git clone of the SVN repository and track 2 remote SVN branches in 2 separate local branches.
# Create and push some commits in the 1st local branch.
# Merge ahead the changes from the 1st local branch into the 2nd. 

After merging, the 2nd branch begins tracking the remote branch of the 1st local branch and it's not possible to commit into the 2nd remote branch.
fields.summary: Remote SVN Branch Tracked Incorrectly After Merge of Local Branches

fields.description: If 'amend' is ticked in the GRI sheet and you hit 'Edit message' it causes the application to freeze. Reported via AAC here: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/173127/interactive-rebase-hangs?page=1
fields.summary: Ticking 'amend commit' then attempting to edit message causes crash in GRI

fields.description:
It took me a while to figure why I was repeatedly being confused when handling branches, then today I found it: In SourceTree (for Mac), on the left hand side, in the overview for the branches, not only the currently switched-to branch is shown in bold font, but also the one which is currently highlighted with the mouse pointer.

The currently switched-to branch is otherwise only marked by the slightly different icon. The currently mouse-highlighted branch is otherwise also marked by it's colored background highlighting.
The mouse-highlighting stays (tho shown in gray background, but still boldface) even when working in other parts of the application, for example the log.

Generally, the less important information of which branch I have previously clicked by mouse is optically dominant over the more important information on which branch I am currently working on.
Took me a while to understand that my brain was mainly confused by the bold typing of the string.

I have attached an edited screenshot which I hope helps my explanation. In the two different cases, I have clicked from one to another branch. First, the master branch is selected, then the NO-Manueld-cruft. You can clearly see that the last clicked item is shown in bold font.
Please note that the branch I am currently working on (in these pictures) is neither of these branches. The current working copy is on MONT-85.
In both cases, the most dominant information in the picture is the least important one, at least as long as that highlighting is persistent over activities in other parts of the application.
fields.summary: SourceTree Branches Overview: currently active and highlighted branch are both shown in bold typeface

fields.description:
When the {{extdiff}} extension in {{.hgrc}} is enabled:
{noformat}
[extensions]
extdiff =
[extdiff]
cmd.diff = /Applications/DiffMerge.app/Contents/MacOS/DiffMerge
{noformat}

SourceTree doesn't show the differences between files in the embedded diff.
fields.summary: Embedded Diff Is Broken When Extdiff Is Enabled in Mercurial

fields.description:
I often use the Dock context menu to switch between windows. I would like a quick shortcut to the Bookmarks window in this menu, so even if the Bookmarks window is closed, it is easily accessible.

I have attached a screenshot of the context menu I speak of, not sure what OSX calls it.
fields.summary: Dock Icon context menu 'Show Bookmarks' option
